example.BM: Dia berasa hati berbunga-bunga apabila menerima hadiah itu.
example.English: She felt overjoyed when she received the gift.

idioms.explanation: Refers to someone who is very dear or precious to you, often a loved one or child.

example.BM: Anak kecil itu adalah buah hati keluarganya.
example.English: The little child is the apple of the family's eye.

idioms.explanation: Feeling sad or reluctant to do something.

example.BM: Dengan hati berat, dia meninggalkan kampung halamannya.
example.English: With a heavy heart, he left his hometown.

example.BM: Hati gembira melihat anak-anaknya berjaya dalam pelajaran.
example.English: She felt joyful seeing her children succeed in their studies.

example.BM: Jangan cakap dengan dia sekarang, dia sedang hati panas.
example.English: Don’t talk to him now; he’s feeling angry.

idioms.explanation: Feeling guilty or having a bad conscience.

example.BM: Dia ada hati kecil kerana tidak menolong kawannya semalam.
example.English: He felt guilty for not helping his friend yesterday.

example.BM: Hati saya tersentuh mendengar cerita sedih itu.
example.English: My heart was touched hearing that sad story.

idioms.explanation: Feeling resentful or holding a grudge.

example.BM: Dia masih ada hati berbisa terhadap bekas kawannya.
example.English: He still holds a grudge against his former friend.

example.BM: Selepas kejadian itu, hatinya menjadi kering.
example.English: After the incident, his heart became numb.

example.BM: Hatinya luka kerana dikhianati oleh sahabat karibnya.
example.English: His heart was wounded because he was betrayed by his best friend.

idioms.explanation: Feeling hurt, upset, or emotionally distressed.

example.BM: Dia makan hati kerana ditinggalkan oleh kekasihnya.
example.English: She felt hurt because she was left by her lover.

example.BM: Rasa hati saya mengatakan ada sesuatu yang tidak kena.
example.English: My gut feeling tells me something is wrong.

example.BM: Dia sakit hati kerana dikhianati oleh sahabatnya.
example.English: He felt heartache because he was betrayed by his friend.

example.BM: Selepas selesaikan masalah, hati saya sejuk.
example.English: After solving the problem, my heart felt at peace.

example.BM: Dia berasa tegang hati sebelum peperiksaan.
example.English: He felt anxious before the exam.

example.BM: Selepas berbincang, hati saya terang.
example.English: After discussing, my mind felt clear.

example.BM: Dia terbakar hati melihat kekasihnya dengan orang lain.
example.English: His heart burned with jealousy seeing his lover with someone else.

example.BM: Dia tertekan hati kerana beban kerja yang banyak.
example.English: He felt emotionally burdened due to the heavy workload.

example.BM: Dia membantu dengan tulus hati.
example.English: He helped with a sincere heart.

example.BM: Usah hati, semuanya akan baik.
example.English: Don’t worry, everything will be fine.

example.BM: Hati-hati di jalan raya.
example.English: Be careful on the road.

idioms.explanation: Being lazy or unwilling to work.

example.BM: Jangan jadi berat tulang, tolong kemas bilik ini.
example.English: Don’t be lazy; help clean up this room.

idioms.explanation: Encourages someone to try something first before making a decision or judgment.

example.BM: Cuba dulu yang baru sebelum membuat keputusan.
example.English: Try the new one first before making a decision.

idioms.explanation: Unexpectedly gaining something valuable or achieving success without much effort.

example.BM: Dia mendapat durian runtuh apabila memenangi loteri.
example.English: He got a windfall when he won the lottery.

example.BM: Dia ringan tulang, sentiasa membantu ibunya di dapur.
example.English: He’s hardworking, always helping his mother in the kitchen.

example.BM: Dengan berat hati, dia terpaksa meminjam wang daripada kawannya.
example.English: Reluctantly, he had to borrow money from his friend.

example.BM: Dia bekerja sehingga berkeringat dingin untuk menyiapkan projek itu.
example.English: He worked until he broke a sweat to complete the project.

idioms.explanation: Creating problems for yourself through your actions.

example.BM: Jika kamu terus berbohong, kamu hanya menggali lubang sendiri.
example.English: If you keep lying, you’re just digging your own hole.

example.BM: Dia selalu mengambil hati bosnya dengan memberi hadiah.
example.English: He always tries to win his boss’s favor by giving gifts.

example.BM: Dia hanya mengangkat bahu apabila diminta membantu.
example.English: He just shrugged when asked to help.

example.BM: Dia menggali lubang untuk mencari air di padang pasir.
example.English: He dug a hole to find water in the desert.

example.BM: Pada masa susah, kita terpaksa mengikat perut.
example.English: During tough times, we had to tighten our belts.

example.BM: Dia sentiasa mengulurkan tangan kepada mereka yang memerlukan.
example.English: He always extends a hand to those in need.

example.BM: Dia berat tangan untuk membantu.
example.English: He’s reluctant to help.

idioms.explanation: Being quick to help or work.

example.BM: Dia ringan tangan, selalu tolong orang.
example.English: He’s quick to help, always assisting others.

example.BM: Jangan buat kerja sambil lewa, nanti hasilnya tidak baik.
example.English: Don’t do work carelessly, or the results won’t be good.

idioms.explanation: Putting in a lot of effort.

example.BM: Kerja keras adalah kunci kejayaan.
example.English: Hard work is the key to success.

example.BM: Jangan buat kerja kosong, fokus pada yang penting.
example.English: Don’t do empty work; focus on what’s important.

example.BM: Dia ada kerja sambilan untuk tambah pendapatan.
example.English: He has a part-time job to supplement his income.

example.BM: Dia pandai dalam kerja tangan seperti menjahit.
example.English: He’s skilled in handwork like sewing.

example.BM: Jangan buat kerja terbang, nanti banyak kesilapan.
example.English: Don’t do work carelessly, or there will be many mistakes.

example.BM: Dia kerja kuat untuk mencapai impiannya.
example.English: He works diligently to achieve his dreams.

example.BM: Kerja sama adalah penting untuk kejayaan projek.
example.English: Teamwork is important for the success of the project.

idioms.translation: There’s a prawn behind the rock.
idioms.explanation: There’s a hidden agenda or ulterior motive.

example.BM: Dia baik sangat dengan saya tiba-tiba, pasti ada udang di sebalik batu.
example.English: He’s suddenly being very nice to me; there must be a hidden agenda.

idioms.explanation: Family ties cannot be broken easily.

example.BM: Walaupun kami bergaduh, air dicincang tidak akan putus.
example.English: Even though we argue, family ties cannot be broken.

idioms.explanation: Being arrogant or full of oneself.

example.BM: Sejak dia naik pangkat, dia jadi besar kepala.
example.English: Since he got promoted, he’s become arrogant.

idioms.explanation: Don’t overdo kindness, as it can be taken advantage of.

example.BM: Jangan terlalu baik dengan dia, buat baik berpada-pada.
example.English: Don’t be too nice to him; do good in moderation.

idioms.explanation: A favored or cherished person, often receiving special treatment or attention.

example.BM: Ali adalah anak emas dalam keluarganya kerana dia selalu mendapat perhatian lebih.
example.English: Ali is the golden child in his family because he always gets extra attention.

idioms.explanation: Someone who doesn’t keep their promises.

example.BM: Dia selalu cakap nak tolong, tapi cakap tak serupa bikin.
example.English: He always says he’ll help, but his words don’t match his actions.

idioms.idiom: Duduk sama rendah, berdiri sama tinggi
idioms.translation: Sitting equally low, standing equally tall.

example.BM: Di sini, kita duduk sama rendah, berdiri sama tinggi.
example.English: Here, we treat everyone equally.

idioms.idiom: Genggam bara api biar sampai jadi arang
idioms.translation: Hold the ember until it turns to charcoal.
idioms.explanation: Persevere through difficulties until you succeed.

example.BM: Kita kena genggam bara api biar sampai jadi arang untuk berjaya.
example.English: We must persevere through difficulties to succeed.

idioms.idiom: Hati gajah sama dilapah, hati kuman sama dicecah
idioms.translation: The elephant’s heart is sliced, the germ’s heart is tasted.
idioms.explanation: Treating everyone equally, regardless of status.

example.BM: Di sini, hati gajah sama dilapah, hati kuman sama dicecah.
example.English: Here, everyone is treated equally, regardless of status.

idioms.idiom: Ikut hati mati, ikut rasa binasa
idioms.translation: Following your heart leads to death, following your desires leads to ruin.
idioms.explanation: Don’t let emotions or desires control your actions.

example.BM: Jangan ikut hati mati, ikut rasa binasa, fikir dulu sebelum buat keputusan.
example.English: Don’t let emotions or desires control your actions; think before making decisions.

idioms.idiom: Jauh di mata, dekat di hati
idioms.translation: Far in sight, close in heart.
idioms.explanation: Missing someone who is physically far away.

example.BM: Walaupun dia di luar negara, jauh di mata, dekat di hati.
example.English: Even though he’s abroad, far in sight, he’s close in heart.

idioms.idiom: Berkawan biar seribu, berkelahi biar satu
idioms.translation: Make a thousand friends, but only fight with one.
idioms.explanation: It’s better to have many friends than many enemies.

example.BM: Berkawan biar seribu, berkelahi biar satu, jangan cari musuh.
example.English: Make a thousand friends, but only fight with one; don’t seek enemies.

idioms.explanation: Having a close and positive friendship.

example.BM: Mereka bersahabat baik sejak kecil.
example.English: They have been good friends since childhood.

idioms.explanation: Willing to accept new ideas or opinions.

example.BM: Dalam perbincangan, kita perlu bersikap terbuka.
example.English: In discussions, we need to be open-minded.

example.BM: Dia bersuara hati tentang masalah yang dihadapinya.
example.English: He spoke from the heart about the problems he faced.

idioms.explanation: A one-sided effort or unrequited love.

example.BM: Hubungan mereka seperti bertepuk sebelah tangan.
example.English: Their relationship is like clapping with one hand—one-sided.

example.BM: Dia berusaha berukir nama dalam bidang seni.
example.English: He’s trying to make a name for himself in the arts.

example.BM: Dia buang muka kerana gagal dalam pertandingan.
example.English: He lost face because he failed in the competition.

example.BM: Jangan cari pasal dengan jiran kita.
example.English: Don’t look for trouble with our neighbor.

example.BM: Dia cari nama dengan menyertai banyak pertandingan.
example.English: He’s seeking fame by joining many competitions.

example.BM: Dia cari untung dalam setiap perniagaan.
example.English: He’s looking for profit in every business.

example.BM: Hubungan mereka bagai aur dengan tebing.
example.English: Their relationship is like bamboo and the riverbank—inseparable.

idioms.idiom: Bagai enau dalam belukar melepaskan pucuk masing-masing
idioms.translation: Like sugar palms in the jungle releasing their shoots.
idioms.explanation: Everyone is looking out for themselves.

example.BM: Dalam dunia bisnes, ramai yang bagai enau dalam belukar.
example.English: In the business world, many people are just looking out for themselves.

idioms.explanation: Feeling very comfortable in a situation.

example.BM: Dia bagai ikan dalam air ketika bermain bola.
example.English: He’s like a fish in water when playing soccer.

idioms.translation: Like a nut forgetting its shell.

example.BM: Jangan bagai kacang lupakan kulit setelah berjaya.
example.English: Don’t forget your roots after achieving success.

idioms.translation: Like a dog and a cat.

example.BM: Adik-beradik itu bagai anjing dengan kucing.
example.English: Those siblings are like a dog and a cat—always fighting.

idioms.translation: Like a bird in a cage.

example.BM: Dia berasa bagai burung dalam sangkar di pejabat itu.
example.English: He feels like a bird in a cage in that office.

idioms.translation: Like a betel nut split in two.
idioms.explanation: Two people who are very similar.

example.BM: Mereka bagai pinang dibelah dua, sangat serupa.
example.English: They’re like a betel nut split in two—very similar.

idioms.translation: Like a cat and a mouse.
idioms.explanation: A relationship where one dominates the other.

example.BM: Hubungan mereka bagai kucing dengan tikus.
example.English: Their relationship is like a cat and a mouse.

idioms.idiom: Bagai pucuk dicita ulam pun tiba
idioms.translation: Like the shoot wished for, the vegetable arrives.
idioms.explanation: Getting exactly what you wished for.

example.BM: Permintaannya bagai pucuk dicita ulam pun tiba.
example.English: His wish came true exactly as he wanted.

example.BM: Mereka bagai api dengan asap, tidak boleh dipisahkan.
example.English: They’re like fire and smoke—inseparable.

idioms.idiom: Bagai enau dalam belukar melepaskan pucuk masing-masing
idioms.translation: Like sugar palms in the jungle releasing their shoots.
idioms.explanation: Everyone is looking out for themselves.

example.BM: Dalam dunia bisnes, ramai yang bagai enau dalam belukar.
example.English: In the business world, many people are just looking out for themselves.

idioms.idiom: Bagai mencurah air ke daun keladi
idioms.translation: Like pouring water on a taro leaf.
idioms.explanation: Giving advice to someone who doesn’t listen.

example.BM: Nasihat saya bagai mencurah air ke daun keladi.
example.English: My advice is like pouring water on a taro leaf—he doesn’t listen.

example.BM: Masalah itu bagai api dalam sekam, tidak kelihatan tetapi berbahaya.
example.English: That problem is like fire in chaff—hidden but dangerous.

example.BM: Hubungan mereka bagai isi dengan kuku.
example.English: Their relationship is like flesh and nails—very close.

idioms.translation: What was once difficult becomes easy with practice.

example.BM: Awalnya susah, tapi alah bisa tegal biasa.
example.English: It was hard at first, but practice made it easier.

idioms.idiom: Berat sama dipikul, ringan sama dijinjing
idioms.translation: Heavy burdens are carried together, light ones are lifted together.

example.BM: Dalam keluarga, kita kena berat sama dipikul, ringan sama dijinjing.
example.English: In a family, we must share responsibilities equally.

idioms.explanation: It’s better to take your time and do things right.

example.BM: Jangan terburu-buru, biar lambat asal selamat.
example.English: Don’t rush; it’s better to be slow but safe.

idioms.idiom: Genggam bara api biar sampai jadi arang
idioms.translation: Hold the ember until it turns to charcoal.
idioms.explanation: Persevere through difficulties until you succeed.

example.BM: Kita kena genggam bara api biar sampai jadi arang untuk berjaya.
example.English: We must persevere through difficulties to succeed.

idioms.idiom: Hendak seribu daya, tak hendak seribu dalih
idioms.translation: If you want it, there are a thousand ways; if you don’t, there are a thousand excuses.
idioms.explanation: Success depends on your willingness to try.

example.BM: Kalau nak berjaya, hendak seribu daya, tak hendak seribu dalih.
example.English: If you want to succeed, there are a thousand ways; if you don’t, there are a thousand excuses.

idioms.idiom: Kalau tidak dipecahkan ruyung, manakan dapat sagunya
idioms.translation: If you don’t break the coconut husk, how will you get the flesh?
idioms.explanation: You have to work hard to achieve success.

example.BM: Kalau tidak dipecahkan ruyung, manakan dapat sagunya.
example.English: If you don’t work hard, you won’t achieve success.

idioms.explanation: Refers to a bride or groom on their wedding day, treated like royalty for that special occasion.

example.BM: Pengantin itu diraikan seperti raja sehari.
example.English: The bride and groom were celebrated like royalty for a day.

idioms.translation: Too shy to ask, you’ll lose your way.
idioms.explanation: Asking for help is better than failing.

example.BM: Jangan malu bertanya, malu bertanya sesat jalan.
example.English: Don’t be shy to ask; asking for help is better than failing.

idioms.explanation: Multitasking or achieving two things at once.

example.BM: Dia sambil menyelam minum air dengan menyelesaikan dua projek serentak.
example.English: He killed two birds with one stone by completing two projects at once.

idioms.translation: Little by little, it becomes a hill.
idioms.explanation: Small efforts accumulate into big results.

example.BM: Tabung sedikit-sedikit, lama-lama jadi bukit.
example.English: Save little by little, and over time, it will grow into a hill.

idioms.translation: If you don’t know it, you won’t love it.

example.BM: Tak kenal maka tak cinta, cubalah dulu sebelum menolak.
example.English: If you don’t know it, you won’t love it; try it first before rejecting it.

example.BM: Tak kenal maka tak cinta, cubalah dulu sebelum menolak.
example.English: If you don’t know it, you won’t love it; try it first before rejecting it.

idioms.explanation: Quiet people often have hidden depths.

example.BM: Dia kelihatan pendiam, tapi air tenang menghanyutkan.
example.English: He seems quiet, but still waters run deep.

idioms.explanation: Refers to the ups and downs or challenges experienced in life.

example.BM: Dia telah melalui asam garam hidup sebelum berjaya.
example.English: He went through the salt and sour of life before succeeding.

idioms.idiom: Biarpun sepandai-pandai tupai melompat, sekali-sekala jatuh juga
idioms.translation: No matter how clever a squirrel is at jumping, it will still fall sometimes.

example.BM: Jangan terlalu yakin, biarpun sepandai-pandai tupai melompat, sekali-sekala jatuh juga.
example.English: Don’t be overconfident; even the cleverest squirrel falls sometimes.

idioms.idiom: Di mana ada kemahuan, di situ ada jalan
idioms.translation: Where there’s a will, there’s a way.

example.BM: Jangan putus asa, di mana ada kemahuan, di situ ada jalan.
example.English: Don’t give up; where there’s a will, there’s a way.

idioms.idiom: Bersatu kita teguh, bercerai kita roboh
idioms.translation: United we stand, divided we fall.

example.BM: Kita kena bersatu, kerana bersatu kita teguh, bercerai kita roboh.
example.English: We must unite because united we stand, divided we fall.

idioms.idiom: Harimau mati meninggalkan belang, manusia mati meninggalkan nama
idioms.translation: A tiger dies leaving its stripes, a person dies leaving their name.
idioms.explanation: Your legacy is what you leave behind.

example.BM: Berbuat baiklah, kerana harimau mati meninggalkan belang, manusia mati meninggalkan nama.
example.English: Do good, because a tiger dies leaving its stripes, a person dies leaving their name.

idioms.idiom: Ikut resmi padi, makin berisi makin tunduk
idioms.translation: Like the rice stalk, the fuller it gets, the lower it bows.
idioms.explanation: The more successful you are, the humbler you should be.

example.BM: Jangan sombong, ikut resmi padi, makin berisi makin tunduk.
example.English: Don’t be arrogant; like the rice stalk, the fuller it gets, the lower it bows.

idioms.translation: Don’t judge a book by its cover.

example.BM: Jangan menilai buku dari kulitnya, dia mungkin baik hati.
example.English: Don’t judge a book by its cover; he might be kind-hearted.

example.BM: Dia sangat keras kepala, susah nak dengar nasihat.
example.English: He’s very hard-headed; it’s hard to get him to listen to advice.

example.BM: Di sini lain padang lain belalang, kita kena hormati adat mereka.
example.English: Here, different fields have different grasshoppers; we must respect their customs.

idioms.translation: Too shy to ask, you’ll lose your way.
idioms.explanation: Asking for help is better than failing.

example.BM: Jangan malu bertanya, malu bertanya sesat jalan.
example.English: Don’t be shy to ask; asking for help is better than failing.

idioms.translation: Put into the basket and carry it yourself.
idioms.explanation: Refers to taking responsibility for one's own actions or decisions.

example.BM: Jika kamu membuat keputusan itu, kamu harus masuk bakul angkat sendiri.
example.English: If you make that decision, you must put it into the basket and carry it yourself.

idioms.explanation: Someone who loves to read and study intensely.

example.BM: Sejak kecil, dia memang ulat buku, selalu menghabiskan masa di perpustakaan.
example.English: Since childhood, he has been a bookworm, always spending time in the library.

idioms.idiom: Berat mata memandang, berat lagi bahu memikul
idioms.translation: It’s hard to see, but even harder to carry.
idioms.explanation: Understanding someone’s struggles is easier than experiencing them.

example.BM: Kita mungkin nampak susah, tapi berat mata memandang, berat lagi bahu memikul.
example.English: We might see it as hard, but it’s harder to experience it.

idioms.idiom: Berat sama dipikul, ringan sama dijinjing
idioms.translation: Heavy burdens are carried together, light ones are lifted together.

example.BM: Dalam keluarga, kita kena berat sama dipikul, ringan sama dijinjing.
example.English: In a family, we must share responsibilities equally.

idioms.explanation: Refers to someone who takes on a task or responsibility without proper preparation or expertise.

example.BM: Dia seperti bidan terjun ketika mencuba memperbaiki kereta itu.
example.English: He was like a midwife jumping in when trying to fix the car.

idioms.idiom: Genggam bara api biar sampai jadi arang
idioms.translation: Hold the ember until it turns to charcoal.
idioms.explanation: Persevere through difficulties until you succeed.

example.BM: Kita kena genggam bara api biar sampai jadi arang untuk berjaya.
example.English: We must persevere through difficulties to succeed.

idioms.idiom: Hujan emas di negeri orang, hujan batu di negeri sendiri
idioms.translation: Golden rain in another’s land, stone rain in your own.
idioms.explanation: No matter how good others’ lives seem, your own is still better.

example.BM: Jangan iri hati, hujan emas di negeri orang, hujan batu di negeri sendiri.
example.English: Don’t be envious; golden rain in another’s land, stone rain in your own.

idioms.translation: The further you travel, the wider your view.

example.BM: Jauh perjalanan, luas pemandangan, banyak pengalaman baru.
example.English: The further you travel, the wider your view; you gain new experiences.

idioms.idiom: Kalah jadi abu, menang jadi arang
idioms.translation: Losing turns you to ash, winning turns you to charcoal.
idioms.explanation: Both winning and losing have consequences.

example.BM: Dalam pertandingan, kalah jadi abu, menang jadi arang.
example.English: In a competition, losing turns you to ash, winning turns you to charcoal.

example.BM: Dia melalui lautan api untuk mencapai kejayaan.
example.English: He went through an ocean of fire to achieve success.

idioms.explanation: Being harmed by something you desire.

example.BM: Jangan tamak, nanti mati semut kerana gula.
example.English: Don’t be greedy, or you’ll end up like ants dying for sugar.

idioms.translation: Like a frog under a coconut shell.

example.BM: Dia seperti katak di bawah tempurung, tidak tahu dunia luar.
example.English: He’s like a frog under a coconut shell, unaware of the outside world.

example.BM: Jangan terlalu yakin, nanti terbang tinggi, jatuh sakit.
example.English: Don’t be overconfident, or you’ll fly high and fall painfully.

idioms.explanation: Rumors often have some truth to them.

example.BM: Ada asap ada api, mungkin ada kebenaran dalam khabar itu.
example.English: Where there’s smoke, there’s fire; there might be some truth to the rumor.

example.BM: Hubungan mereka bagai isi dengan kuku.
example.English: Their relationship is like flesh and nails—very close.

idioms.translation: The peg is bigger than the post.

example.BM: Jangan besar pasak daripada tiang, nanti susah.
example.English: Don’t spend more than you earn, or you’ll face difficulties.

idioms.idiom: Biar putih tulang, jangan putih mata
idioms.translation: Better to die than to be humiliated.
idioms.explanation: Pride is more important than life.

example.BM: Dia lebih rela biar putih tulang, jangan putih mata.
example.English: He’d rather die than be humiliated.

idioms.explanation: Someone who doesn’t keep their promises.

example.BM: Dia selalu cakap nak tolong, tapi cakap tak serupa bikin.
example.English: He always says he’ll help, but his words don’t match his actions.

idioms.explanation: Quiet people often have hidden talents.

example.BM: Dia diam-diam ubi berisi, pandai dalam banyak perkara.
example.English: He’s quietly talented, skilled in many things.

idioms.translation: After the honey is gone, the husk is thrown away.

example.BM: Jangan jadi orang yang habis madu sepah dibuang.
example.English: Don’t be someone who’s discarded after being used.

idioms.explanation: Don’t ruin relationships, as you might need them later.

example.BM: Jangan bakar jambatan dengan bekas rakan sekerja.
example.English: Don’t burn bridges with former colleagues.

example.BM: Dia seperti kera sumbang, selalu bising.
example.English: He’s like a noisy monkey, always making noise.

idioms.translation: Like mushrooms growing after the rain.
idioms.explanation: Something that appears quickly and in large numbers.

example.BM: Kedai kopi baru macam cendawan tumbuh selepas hujan.
example.English: New coffee shops are popping up like mushrooms after the rain.

idioms.idiom: Masuk kandang kambing mengembek, masuk kandang kerbau menguak
idioms.translation: Enter a goat’s pen, bleat; enter a buffalo’s pen, moo.
idioms.explanation: Adapt to the customs of the place you’re in.

example.BM: Di tempat baru, kena masuk kandang kambing mengembek, masuk kandang kerbau menguak.
example.English: In a new place, you must adapt to the local customs.

idioms.translation: Looking for a needle in a haystack.
idioms.explanation: Searching for something very difficult to find.

example.BM: Mencari kunci yang hilang itu seperti mencari jarum dalam jerami.
example.English: Looking for the lost key is like searching for a needle in a haystack.

idioms.explanation: Creating problems for yourself through your actions.

example.BM: Jika kamu terus berbohong, kamu hanya menggali lubang sendiri.
example.English: If you keep lying, you’re just digging your own hole.

idioms.translation: Measuring the shirt on your own body.
idioms.explanation: Judging others based on your own standards.

example.BM: Jangan mengukur baju di badan sendiri, setiap orang berbeza.
example.English: Don’t judge others based on your own standards; everyone is different.

idioms.idiom: Murah di mulut, mahal di timbangan
idioms.translation: Cheap in the mouth, expensive on the scale.
idioms.explanation: Easy to say, but hard to do.

example.BM: Janji itu murah di mulut, mahal di timbangan.
example.English: Promises are easy to make but hard to keep.

idioms.translation: The rice has turned to porridge.

example.BM: Sudah terlambat, nasi sudah menjadi bubur.
example.English: It’s too late; what’s done cannot be undone.

example.BM: Dia panjang akal, selalu ada cara untuk menyelesaikan masalah.
example.English: He’s resourceful; he always finds a way to solve problems.

example.BM: Jangan biarkan isu ini pecah belah keluarga kita.
example.English: Don’t let this issue break our family apart.

example.BM: Dia dapat putih mata kerana gagal dalam ujian.
example.English: He felt humiliated because he failed the test.
